persona.name: Skyler Nguyen-Pham

occupation.title: Part-time Preschool Assistant & Undergraduate Student
occupation.organization: Riverside Community Preschool (non-profit) / Portland State University (student)
occupation.description: Skyler splits time between being a university student and working part-time (20-25 hours/week) at a local non-profit preschool. As a preschool assistant their responsibilities include supervising children aged 6 months to 4 years, preparing simple lesson materials based on lead teacher plans, assisting with diapering/toileting and naps, facilitating outdoor play, preparing and serving snacks that follow allergy plans, communicating daily with parents, documenting developmental milestones for the lead teacher, and helping to maintain the classroom environment (sanitizing toys, arranging art supplies). They often translate written notices into Vietnamese for a few families. Skyler is also responsible for supporting inclusive practice for children with diverse needs and occasionally leads circle-time activities and short story sessions. Skills relevant to this role: basic curriculum planning, child observation and documentation, nonviolent communication, basic first aid and infant/child CPR, bilingual communication (English-Vietnamese), and budgeting for classroom supplies. Challenges include unpredictable hours, low pay without benefits, and emotional exhaustion during busy weeks when children or family members are sick.

persona.residence: Portland, Oregon, USA (Inner Northeast - urban, cultural neighborhood close to community centers and a small state university)
persona.education: Undergraduate (Some college completed toward a Bachelor of Arts in Early Childhood Education at Portland State University). Currently enrolled part-time, completed general education requirements, working on observation hours and practicum in a community preschool. Coursework includes child development, family engagement, developmental psychology, and inclusive classroom strategies. Has taken community workshops in bilingual education and trauma-informed care.
long_term_goals: To complete a bachelor's degree in Early Childhood Education within the next 3 years while balancing family responsibilities.
To open a small, community-oriented bilingual preschool co-op that serves low-income families and prioritizes culturally-responsive curricula.
To secure steady, full-time work in early childhood education and access benefits (healthcare, retirement) to provide stability for the family.
To build an intergenerational support network (chosen family + extended relatives) so the children grow up connected to both American and Vietnamese cultural roots.
To buy a modest, energy-efficient house in a safe neighborhood with space for a backyard and a small vegetable garden.
To be an advocate for accessible childcare policy at the local level and help shape programs that helped Skyler when they needed them.
To learn basic home repair and small-scale carpentry so they can save on maintenance and teach practical skills to their children.
To achieve a healthier balance between caregiving, study, and self-care—less burnout and more sustainable routines.
To travel with the family back to Vietnam at least once so the children meet family elders and connect to heritage.
To remain politically and civically engaged and use personal experience to mentor younger student-parents.
persona.style: Warm, conversational, practical and slightly informal. Skyler speaks with a Portland-area American English accent with occasional inflections from family Vietnamese expressions (code-switches to Vietnamese words for food, family terms, and endearments). They typically address kids with a sing-song, patient cadence and adults with a friendly, direct tone. When tired or stressed they uses short sentences and apologizes often. Mannerisms include: rubbing the back of their neck when anxious, a frequent half-smile when deflecting praise, using hand gestures to demonstrate actions when explaining things to children, and a habit of repeating instructions twice to ensure understanding. Skyler prefers layered, comfortable clothing—cardigans, soft tees, leggings or relaxed jeans, and usually wears a crossbody diaper bag. They keep their phone on vibrate and use a shared family calendar app (Cozi) and texting for quick logistics. In formal settings (university meetings, parent-teacher conferences) Skyler shifts into a more structured mode—notes out, prepared questions, and formal salutations—yet still prefers to keep interactions friendly rather than overly formal. Uses they/them pronouns and will correct people gently but firmly if misgendered. On social media they present a mix of candid parenting updates, student-life memes, and community activism shares; they avoid flashy or curated 'influencer' aesthetics.

traits: Empathetic — deeply attuned to children's emotions and the feelings of close friends and family.
Pragmatic — focuses on realistic, incremental solutions rather than grand plans when stressed.
Resilient — bounces back after setbacks but needs recovery time.
Organized in some domains — good at tracking appointments and children's needs; messy in personal creative spaces.
Insecure about finances and career trajectory, which sometimes shows as self-doubt.
Playful and silly with kids — loves making up songs and games.
Protective and fiercely loyal to family and chosen community.
Social and enjoys small-group interactions more than large gatherings.
Curious and enjoys learning new child-centered pedagogies and parenting hacks.
Frugal but generous — will stretch resources for someone in need.
Activist leanings — volunteers locally for childcare access and immigrant rights.
Anxious under unpredictable schedules — cortisol spikes when routines break.
Adaptable — able to improvise childcare, meals, or study time when needed.
Reflective — journals occasionally and reassesses priorities regularly.

big_five.openness: Moderately High. Enjoys new ideas about pedagogy, cultural recipes, and creative children's activities; interested in travel and heritage but constrained by resources.
big_five.conscientiousness: Medium-High. Reliable for childcare and school deadlines, strong in planning daily logistics, but sometimes struggles with long-term consistency when overwhelmed.
big_five.extraversion: Medium. Energized by small-group socializing and community events; finds large parties draining.
big_five.agreeableness: High. Cooperative, compassionate, and people-oriented; tends to avoid confrontation but will stand firm on children's wellbeing.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium-High. Experiences worry about finances, children's health, and academic progress, with occasional sleepless nights and emotional fatigue.

interests: Child development theory and play-based learning approaches (Montessori influences, Reggio Emilia ideas).
Bilingual children's literature—picture books in both English and Vietnamese.
Simple, fresh cooking—stir-frys, pho-like broths adapted for toddlers, and batch-cooked rice bowls.
Local community events: family storytime at the library, farmers' markets, neighborhood potlucks.
Second-hand shopping for kids' clothes and toys (thrift stores, Buy Nothing groups).
Podcasts about parenting, social justice, and affordable living (e.g., parenting podcasts that focus on low-income families).
Upcycling and DIY activities with kids—paper crafts, nature walks for art materials.
Mindfulness apps for short guided exercises during nap times (e.g., 5-10 minute breathing practices).
Informal family photography—phone photos and printed collage walls rather than curated Instagram grids.
Community organizing—attending city council meetings about childcare subsidies or immigrant services.
Ethnic restaurants that feel family-friendly and affordable (local pho places, bánh mì shops).
Outdoor play and local playgrounds; parks with shaded areas for infants.
Learning Vietnamese songs and lullabies to sing to the children.
Simple home gardening—potted herbs on a balcony or windowsill.
Documentaries about immigration histories and community resilience.
Craft coffee in moderation—prefers drip coffee or small lattes; often chooses decaf after midday while parenting.
Comfortable local music—indie folk playlists, soft Vietnamese pop music from family playlists.
Practical smartphone apps: shared calendar (Cozi), grocery list apps (Out of Milk), public transit app (TriMet), budgeting app (Mint or a manual spreadsheet).
Volunteer activities—helping at food distribution events and community childcare co-ops.
Watching educational kids' shows in short bursts (e.g., Sesame Street clips, bilingual story apps).
likes: Warm banh mi sandwiches and strong black coffee in the morning.
Slow, steady mornings when the kids sleep in and there is time to prep breakfasts.
Neighborhood cafes with high chairs and changing tables—kid-friendly amenities are a must.
Handmade gifts from the children (crayon drawings, toothless grins with art), and keeping them in a memory box.
Shared meals with extended family when possible—multi-generational dinners.
Planning small rituals like Friday pancake breakfasts or Sunday story sessions.
Community potlucks where neighbors bring different cultural dishes.
Organized bins for toys labeled with pictures so the kids can learn to tidy up.
Affordable local laundromat with a kid safe play corner for social interactions.
Finding a perfect thrifted jacket for the kids at a great price.
Quick, one-pot meals that can be reheated easily during night awakenings.
Using white-noise machines and blackout curtains to help infants nap.
Simple, predictable bedtime routines—bath, story, lullaby.
Making weekly study blocks after kids' naps to keep coursework progressing.
Bilingual children's books that include both languages side-by-side.
Community supported agriculture (CSA) share on a small scale—fresh vegetables once a week.
Receiving emotional support from a small circle of close friends.
Practical baby gear—reliable stroller, cloth diapers for cost-saving, and a well-used baby carrier.
Seasonal rituals—pumpkin patches in autumn, library summer reading programs.
Local library branches with generous kids' programs and free access to materials.
dislikes: Overpriced parenting 'must-have' culture—being judged for not buying certain gear.
Long bureaucratic waits for social services and childcare subsidies.
Judgmental comments about their parenting choices, especially from strangers or in-laws.
Crowded, noisy restaurants that are not kid-accommodating.
People who equate low income with lack of care or intelligence.
Stereotypes about immigrants and Asian Americans.
Unreliable public transit when trying to coordinate drop-offs and school.
High-pressure comparisons on social media about parenting milestones.
Long academic readings without practical application (prefers applied pedagogy).
Stores without family restrooms or changing facilities.
Being asked invasive questions about marital or fertility choices by acquaintances.
Poor-quality, cheaply made toys that break quickly and are unsafe.
Rigid school policies that don't account for low-income or immigrant families' realities.
Having to choose between childcare and pursuing education or work.
Lack of Vietnamese food options when craving a taste of home for the children.
Uncompassionate customer service when dealing with family emergencies.

coffee_preferences: Prefers single-origin drip or small latte; often orders oat milk lattes when treating themself.
Likes cafes with quiet corners and outlets to tether a laptop during late nap-time study sessions.
Avoids big chain drive-thru culture for longer social interactions; supports local businesses when possible.
Uses a reusable travel mug and prefers small cafes that offer discounts for it.
book_preferences: Favorites include bilingual picture books, illustrated parenting guides, and memoirs about immigrant families.
Keeps a small reading stack: a parenting paperback, a Vietnamese children's storybook, and an approachable child development text.
Borrowing from the library is a preferred habit due to budget constraints.
child_play_preferences: Favors open-ended toys (wooden blocks, fabric scarves) over screen-based entertainment.
Creates sensory bins with rice, beans, and safe kitchen tools for tactile play.
Enjoys neighborhood nature walks and collecting leaves for crafts.
social_activities: Enjoys potluck-style gatherings where everyone pitches in rather than expensive outings.
Participates in a small parent support group that meets biweekly at the community center.

beliefs: Children learn best through play that is guided but not overly structured.
Accessible, quality early childhood education should be a public good, not a privilege.
Family includes blood relatives and chosen family—both matter equally for support.
Being a good parent does not require expensive gear but requires presence and responsiveness.
Education can be a pathway to stability but must be flexible for parents who work and care for children.
Bilingualism is an asset for cognitive development and cultural identity, and it should be nurtured from infancy.
Community safety is built through relationships and mutual aid more than punitive policing.
Immigrant stories and histories should be part of local school curricula.
Healthcare access is essential; gaps in coverage are a community problem.
Public transit investment affects family life directly—reliable transit enables work and study opportunities.
Social programs (childcare subsidies, SNAP, WIC) are lifelines, not handouts.
Local libraries and community centers are among the most valuable public resources for families.
Small acts of kindness ripple through communities and can significantly help stressed parents.
Mental health care should be affordable and stigma-free, especially for parents with postpartum concerns.
Gender identity and expression should be respected and taught as part of kindness education to children.
Cultural food and rituals should be preserved and shared within families for identity continuity.
It's important to advocate for parental leave policies that don't penalize low-income workers.
Volunteering in the community provides more than service—it builds reciprocal relationships and social capital.
Frugality is not the same as stinginess; it can be a strategy of care for children.
Religious faith is personal and can coexist with secular parenting philosophies; Skyler is culturally Vietnamese with occasional Buddhist-influenced rituals but not strictly religious.
Access to green space is crucial for child development and family wellbeing.
Early intervention services for developmental delays should be proactive and non-stigmatizing.
People make mistakes and should be given opportunities to learn from them rather than ostracized.
School systems should accommodate linguistic diversity rather than penalize it.
Affordable housing is directly connected to childhood stability and educational outcomes.
Representation matters: kids benefit from seeing diverse family structures and identities in books and media.
Economic policy decisions (minimum wage, childcare funding) have immediate effects on families like Skyler's.
Self-care is necessary for caregivers; it's not selfish to set boundaries and ask for help.
Technology is a tool—useful for connection and learning but should be limited in early childhood.
Art and music exposure in the early years supports language and emotional expression.
People in small neighborhoods can do a lot to reduce isolation among parents—doorway conversations, sharing meals, swapping babysitting.
Systems are imperfect; working within and alongside them to improve access is worthwhile and necessary.
A non-punitive approach to parenting (focus on repair, empathy) yields better outcomes than shame and punishment.
Public spaces should be designed with families in mind—changing tables, benches, shade, safe play areas.
skills: Practical childcare skills: diapering, bottle preparation, soothing techniques, nap routines, safe sleep knowledge.
Basic lesson preparation for preschool: selecting read-alouds, simple songs, and age-appropriate activities.
Bilingual communication in English and Vietnamese—can translate simple forms and convey key messages to Vietnamese-speaking relatives.
First aid and infant/child CPR certified (community class within last 18 months).
Time-blocking and micro-planning: blocks study into 45-minute increments during nap times.
Basic budgeting and bill-tracking; uses spreadsheets and budgeting apps to manage limited resources.
Meal planning and batch-cooking for quick toddler-friendly meals (steamed vegetables, simple proteins, broths).
Advocacy and community organizing: writing public comments for city council, organizing childcare collective meetings.
Basic troubleshooting of household items—changing light bulbs, unclogging a sink with a plunger, swapping a diaper bag strap.
Comfortable with public transit systems and stroller boarding; can coordinate multi-stop errands efficiently.
Child observation and documentation skills for early childhood assessment forms.
Conflict mediation among parents in playgroups—calm, neutral facilitation.
Use of common educational tech used in preschool settings (Seesaw for documenting child learning, Google Drive for shared lesson plans).
Comfortable public speaking in small community meetings and parent groups.
Sewing basics—mending ripped kid clothes and sewing on buttons.

general: Tends to overprepare for routine days (extra diapers, snacks, and a small first-aid kit in the stroller).
Sends a nightly short voice-note to their spouse summarizing the children's day and any concerns.
Keeps a small pocket notebook for observations about child milestones and study deadlines.
Apologizes frequently, sometimes excessively, in social interactions to smooth potential friction.
Brings a small set of quiet toys and books to adult gatherings to keep children engaged.
Is quick to offer help to neighbors (watching a child for 20 minutes, dropping off soup) but sometimes neglects asking for help in return.
Uses humor and songs to redirect toddlers' tantrums.
Reads parenting blogs and research articles in short bursts between tasks.
Prefers texting to phone calls for logistics but will call if the situation feels urgent.
Avoids escalating arguments; uses cooling-off periods and scheduled conversations with their spouse.

morning: Wakes at 6:15 AM on weekdays when kids have an early start; otherwise around 7 AM on weekends.
Preps coffee and a simple breakfast (rice porridge or toast), packs snacks and diaper bag the night before when possible.
Feeds youngest, does quick diaper changes, and puts on a playlist of Vietnamese and English children's songs during the morning routine.
Checks shared family calendar for appointments, classes, and work shifts.
Leaves for preschool work or classes with a 10–15 minute buffer to account for transit and stroller boarding.
workday/studyday: At work: arranges activity corners, documents two or three anecdotal notes about child behavior for the lead teacher, and helps with snack times.
During campus days: attends a morning or afternoon class, studies in the student union during nap overlap, and meets with a practicum supervisor weekly.
Eats quickly between tasks—leftovers or a prepared rice bowl—and often snacks on fruit or granola bars.
Uses lunch breaks for quick errands (library pickup, grocery run) or a short phone call to spouse about childcare logistics.
evening: Arrives home, changes into comfortable clothes, does a quick family dinner focused on simple, vegetable-forward dishes.
Bath time followed by reading two short stories and singing a lullaby in Vietnamese and English.
After kids are asleep, spends 30–60 minutes on coursework or household admin, then attempts a 10–15 minute mindfulness practice.
Frequently reviews the next day's plan and preps for breakfasts/snacks to reduce morning stress.
weekend: Visits a farmer's market or a community park in the morning, trading playdates with other parents in the afternoon.
Schedules at least one longer family phone call/video chat with extended family (usually their parents or siblings abroad or in another city).
Uses Saturday evenings for community events or small gatherings; Sunday for slower family time and lesson planning for the week.

health.physical: Generally good physical health. Has a history of seasonal asthma managed with an as-needed inhaler (has one at home and a travel inhaler in the diaper bag). Up-to-date on routine vaccinations. Experienced a normal-term pregnancy with the youngest; postpartum recovery was typical. Occasionally has lower back pain from lifting toddlers and carrying a car seat; uses stretches and local free PT resources when needed. Dental care sometimes delayed due to finances but keeps up with basic hygiene.
health.mental: Skyler experiences periodic anxiety, especially tied to finances, academic deadlines, and childcare logistics. They had mild postpartum anxiety following the most recent birth, which improved with social support and short-term therapy via a sliding-scale clinic. No current suicidal ideation. Uses community support groups and mindfulness apps for management. Reports sporadic sleep deprivation due to infant night-wakings and occasional night anxiety about finances or 'falling behind' academically.
health.medical_history: No chronic metabolic conditions (no diabetes or hypertension). Seasonal allergies. No major surgeries. Infant and child healthcare follow standard pediatric schedules. Uses community clinic for most healthcare needs due to low income.
health.health_behaviors: Attempts 20–30 minutes of movement several times a week (walks with stroller, occasional bike rides). Prioritizes handwashing and cleaning toys during cold/flu season. Tries to maintain a mostly plant-forward diet with occasional proteins. Limits caffeine after midday to avoid affecting infants during shared caregiving times. Uses free mental health counseling services occasionally and participates in a parent support group.

relationships.name: Alex Tran-Patel
relationships.description: Married partner (they met in community college). Alex works part-time in a local unionized warehouse and takes evening classes for logistics. Co-parents reliably; they share finances and coordinate schedules through a shared calendar. Relationship is supportive but sometimes strained due to financial stress and unpredictable shift work. They resolve conflicts through scheduled check-ins and a rotating 'who handles bedtime' system on busy nights.

relationships.name: Child - Minh (called 'Mini')
relationships.description: 4 years old, energetic, curious, attending preschool two mornings a week. Loves blocks, drawing, and being read to in Vietnamese and English. Sleeps through the night most nights. Has been toilet training with gradual success.

relationships.name: Child - An (called 'Annie')
relationships.description: 1 year old, breastfed as an infant and currently taking solids. Sleeps in their own crib in the parents' room. Has frequent teething-related awakenings and uses a pacifier at times. Enjoys being carried in a soft structured carrier and listening to lullabies.

relationships.name: Skyler's mother - Lien Nguyen
relationships.description: Lives in a nearby suburb; provides intermittent childcare and cultural connection. Generous but traditional—sometimes offers parenting advice that Skyler respectfully negotiates with. Speaks primarily Vietnamese; Skyler facilitates translation and cultural continuity.

relationships.name: Skyler's father - Huy Pham
relationships.description: Works part-time in a family restaurant; practical and supportive, helps with home-cooked meals and occasionally watches the kids for several hours on weekends.
relationships.notes: Has a complicated health history (type 2 diabetes) that Skyler helps monitor remotely during visits and calls.

relationships.name: Close friend group
relationships.description: A small group of 4–6 peers from college and neighborhood who share babysitting swaps, emotional support, and occasional dinners. They meet biweekly and run a text chain for quick help requests.

relationships.name: Lead teacher - Marissa
relationships.description: Experienced early childhood educator who mentors Skyler in classroom techniques and provides letters of reference for future work. Encourages Skyler's bilingual programming ideas.

relationships.name: Classmate - Jasmine
relationships.description: Works on group assignments together and exchanges childcare coverage during finals week.

relationships.name: Neighbor - Rosa
relationships.description: Retired school aide who adores the kids and provides wisdom and short-term childcare when emergencies arise.

other_facts: Married at age 22 in a small family ceremony that combined Vietnamese tea rituals and a simple courthouse ritual; the event was inexpensive but meaningful.
Has two children under 6 (a 4-year-old and a 1-year-old), both living at home and are the primary focus of daily life.
Uses a hyphenated last name Nguyen-Pham due to blended family naming choices and keeps that name for cultural recognition.
Was the first in their immediate family to attend college in the U.S.; parents emigrated in the 1990s.
Grew up in a neighborhood with many Vietnamese immigrant families and learned a lot of recipes and cultural practices from elders.
Spent summers as a teenager working in their parents' restaurant doing prep work and learning time-management under pressure.
Dropped out temporarily after becoming a parent the first time but returned to school part-time two years later.
Has a well-worn cloth diapering kit and prefers cloth for cost and environmental reasons when feasible.
Keeps a small memory box with the children's hospital bracelets, first shoes, and a hand-copied lullaby from Skyler's mother.
Once led a small community petition to improve a local playground's shade structures after noticing many kids avoiding midday play due to sun exposure.
Is a member of a local Buy Nothing group and has received many useful items that helped during early parenting months (carrier, bassinet, clothes).
Has a beloved 15-year-old hand-me-down stroller that still works despite wear; it's a point of pride and a little sentimental.
Keeps letters from a high school teacher who encouraged them to pursue education and references them when doubt surfaces.
Had a close friend who experienced housing instability; that experience motivated Skyler to advocate for affordable housing locally.
Once organized a small 'parent relief' group where parents in the neighborhood traded short blocks of babysitting time to allow others to run errands or nap.
Has a soft spot for rainy-day crafts and keeps a drawer of scrap paper, stickers, and safe scissors specifically for art time.
Is allergic to penicillin (documented) and always checks with medical providers before receiving prescriptions.
Keeps a laminated 'family emergency' card in the diaper bag with contacts, allergies, and medical info.
Has a scar on the left knee from falling off a bike as a child; it's a little story they tell their kids about learning to get back up.
Keeps an old cassette tape of their mother's voice singing a lullaby; it's been digitized and sometimes played for the kids.
Was once part of a campus theater production as a stagehand; they enjoy making simple props for kids' dramatic play.
Has a fear of flying long distances with young children due to logistical stress and tends to prefer train or car trips when possible.
Participates in a co-op babysitting circle with three other families where time is traded rather than paid.
Had a brief internship at a family services non-profit where they learned about eligibility processes for benefits—experience that helps navigate paperwork.
Keeps a short list of emergency childcare options and local sliding-scale clinics pinned to the fridge.
Has a recurring dream about finishing their degree and opening a preschool with a garden classroom—a vivid motivator on tough days.
Was once reprimanded by a landlord about noise from kids; turned it into a proactive conversation about quiet hours and better soundproofing rather than a fight.
Is awkward with small talk at large gatherings but thrives in meaningful one-on-one conversations.
Loves the combination of Vietnamese flavors with Pacific Northwest produce—often makes a fusion of traditional broths with seasonal vegetables.
Has a habit of writing small affirmations for themselves on index cards and tucking them into the diaper bag for rough days.
Kept a pregnancy journal for each child and occasionally reads excerpts to remember small details and milestones.
Once campaigned with other parents for later school start times for a nearby preschool program to better align with working parents' schedules.
Has had to navigate microaggressions at work and school (assumptions about English proficiency or family roles) and now practices short, calm rebuttals to de-escalate situations.
Keeps a playlist titled 'Skyler's Calm' with 40 tracks used for winding down during nap time and for studying in short blocks.
Has a ritual of making a simple special breakfast (pancakes with fruit) the first Saturday of each month to celebrate small family wins.
Learns Vietnamese songs from their mother via phone calls and then records voice memos so the kids can hear the maternal accent when Grandma isn't physically present.
Has a standing appointment at a low-cost legal clinic to keep documents like housing lease and guardianship paperwork in order.
Once organized a small fundraiser among neighbors to buy better winter coats for two families who couldn't afford them, and the experience reinforced Skyler's belief in mutual aid.
Dreams of the day their kids will teach them something new—currently hoping Mini will teach them a new playground game.
